learning_outcomes.description: Understand insect physiology in varied environmental, economic and social contexts
Relate form with function to explain physiological adaptations in insects
Describe how insect physiology is experimentally studied and manipulated in various applied entomology contexts
Read and appraise entomological literature critically
Demonstrate technical and professional engagement skills related to future careers in entomology

assessments.task_description:
Throughout the semester, you will be engaging with lecturers in simulated work environments related to entomological research. This includes:

  • Applied learning (APP) classes where you are working systematically through varied activities including but not limited to journal clubs, computer-based problem-solving, discussions etc. Researchers engage frequently in similar settings to share their findings, discuss recent work done by other scientists, and strategize the direction of their own research.
  • Practicals (PRA) where you will conduct your own mini-research project, including ideation, experimental design, execution, data collection and analysis of results. You will not be required to produce a formal scientific report per se but you are expected to maintain a detailed logbook and journal that is hand-written (with the exception of statistical analyses which should be provided in graphical form and where relevant accompanying code).

Based on your engagement with your lecturers throughout the semester, and any evidence submitted by the end of the research project, your holistic professional engagement will be assessed. The key areas of your professionalism we are interested in:

  • proficiency in professional communication (in written form but also including non-verbal cues)
  • proficiency in professional behaviour (including risk management and lab safety)
  • proficiency in scientific research skills
  • proficiency in data analysis skills
  • (bonus) your leadership skills (we will discuss this in class)

Evidence to assess may includes:

  • your active participation during class, during group conversations or one-on-one engagement with your lecturers
  • your participation on Discussion Board
  • interaction (collegiality) with your peers
  • your time management and commitment (including punctuality)
  • the quality of your proposed and executed experiment
  • the quality of your note-taking in your research logbook
  • the quality of your data analysis and data visualisation (from your project data)
  • your ability to solve problems during unexpected events while you undertake your research project

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You will deliver an engaging 5 minute presentation based on your own desktop research about an area related to applied entomology. The topic of your presentation will be randomly assigned to you in Week 5 of semester. You should deliver the presentation verbally, and may use visual aids (slides) or props.

You are being assessed on:

  • ability to distil credible evidence (primary literature) to adequately address your assigned topic
  • ability to communicate genuinely, authentically and confidently
  • ability to think critical and provoke curiosity through constructive criticism
  • ability to respond to questions effectively (during a dedicated Q&A session after your presentation)

Some example topics:

  • Why haven't we discovered all the stick insects?
  • Are sex pheromone traps really effective?
  • Are ants in the movie ANTZ portrayed accurately?
  • Are biological control strategies a waste of time and money?
  • Will fire ants ever be eradicated in Queensland?

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You will be scheduled to deliver 5 minutes presentation in-person, and submit a copy via Turnitin link by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
You will complete the Collaborative Exam during a scheduled time during the end-of-semester exam block. More information will be provided in class.

The exam will assess content on:

  • self-directed learning (SDL) modules
  • applied learning (APP) classes that have taken place throughout the semester 

During the exam, you may:

  • refer to any resources and have internet access (essentially, it is an open-book test)
  • engage in discussion with your peers

You should expect questions in the exam to assess your higher-order thinking skills, critical reading skills, and written communication skills. There will be little to no questions in the exam that requires you to rely on recalling knowledge.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
